{{Infobox person | name = Hal Sparks | image = File:Hal_Sparks.jpg | image_size = | caption = Sparks in 2009 | birth_name =Harry Magee Sparks III <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lgbtqnation.com/2012/08/hal-sparks-from-queer-as-folk-to-stand-up-and-everywhere-in-between/|title=Hal Sparks, from 'Queer As Folk' to real-life role as comedian, straight ally|work=LGBTQ Nation}}</ref> | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1969|9|25}} | birth_place = [[Cincinnati]], [[Ohio]], [[United States]] | occupation = Actor, comedian, musician, television personality, political commentator | children = 1 | years_active = 1987–present | website = {{Official website|http://www.halsparks.com/}} }} '''Harry Magee "Hal" Sparks III''' (born September 25, 1969) is an American actor, comedian, musician, political commentator, and television personality. He is known for his contributions to [[VH1]], hosting [[E!]]'s ''[[Talk Soup]]'', and the role of [[Michael Novotny]] on the American television series ''[[Queer as Folk (U.S. TV series)|Queer as Folk]]'', Donald Davenport in ''[[Lab Rats (US TV series)|Lab Rats]]'' and as the voice of Tak in ''[[Tak and the Power of Juju (TV series)|Tak and the Power of Juju]]'' television series and video games.
==Early life== Sparks was born on September 25, 1969 in [[Cincinnati]], [[Ohio]], but grew up in Peaks Mill, [[Kentucky]].
When he was 14 years old, he moved to the [[Chicago]] area and enrolled at [[New Trier High School]] in [[Winnetka, Illinois]], where he entered the theater department. Despite some initial opposition by his father, by 15 he began performing standup comedy and by 17 he won the title of "Chicago's Funniest Teenager" from the ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Official Website|url=http://halsparks.com/bio/}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=NBC DFW: Stand-Up Sit-Down: Hal Sparks|url=http://www.nbcdfw.com/the-scene/events/Stand-up-Sit-Down-Hal-Sparks-98041454.html|work=[[KXAS-TV|NBC DFW]]|date=July 8, 2010|accessdate=February 5, 2016}}</ref>
==Career== [[File:Hal Sparks by Gage Skidmore.jpg|right|thumb|Sparks in 2016.]] While still in high school, he became the host of the short-run Saturday game show [[Treasure Mall]] in 1988, just months shy of his 19th birthday. Upon graduation, Sparks moved to Los Angeles and after ten long years of paying his dues, he got his major TV break when he was hired to host ''[[Talk Soup]]'' in 1999.
He would go on to independently produce his first standup comedy DVD ''Escape from Halcatraz'' in 2008.
Sparks is a regular guest on such programs as CNN's ''[[Your $$$$$]]'', ''[[The Joy Behar Show]]'' and ''[[The View (U.S. TV series)|The View]]'' when he's not hosting his own weekly progressive radio show.<ref>{{cite news|title=Edge New York New York: Hal Sparks Tackles Politics, Civil Rights, Radio, and... Disney?|url=http://www.edgenewyork.com/index.php?ch=entertainment&sc=television&sc3=&id=118577&pg=1|date=April 19, 2011}}</ref> He's also participated in the Progressive Voices Cruise in 2009 and 2010. In 2011 he joined [[Stephanie Miller]] and [[John Fugelsang]] for the successful ''Sexy Liberal Comedy Tour'' in various cities across the country. This tour topped more than a million dollars in ticket sales while raising money for local progressive causes.<ref>{{cite news|title=Can a comedy tour be 'sexy and liberal?'|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/culturemonster/2011/10/at-each-stop-on-stephanie-millers-nationwide-sexy-liberal-comedy-tour-launched-at-madison-wisconsins-barrymore-the.html|work=[[Los Angeles Times]] | date=October 22, 2011}}</ref>
===Radio=== Sparks appears as a regular guest and fill-in host on the national ''[[Stephanie Miller]] Radio Show'', providing three hours of commentary and humor on Wednesday mornings. The program is known as "Hump Days with Hal", and is broadcast weekly from his official U-stream channel. Sparks has also appeared as guest host for [[Norman Goldman]]'s Los Angeles-based show.<ref>The Norman Goldman Show - Where Justice is Served, ''normangoldman.com''</ref> Sparks broadcast hosting was also made available through Goldman's "Beyond the Norm" segments.
He continued this free "behind the scenes" U-stream show for his listeners and fans. In June 2010 he got his own radio program on ''Chicago's Progressive Talk'' as host of ''The Hal Sparks Radio Program (megaworldwide)'', which broadcasts between 11am and 1pm each Saturday.<ref>{{cite web|title=Hal Sparks Live|url=http://www.ustream.tv./channel/halsparkslive}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Hal Sparks - The Hal Sparks Show |url=http://chicagosprogressivetalk.com/includes/news_items/2/news_items_more.php?id%3D84%26section_id%3D2 |accessdate=May 4, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110429123337/http://chicagosprogressivetalk.com/includes/news_items/2/news_items_more.php?id=84&section_id=2 |archivedate=April 29, 2011 }}</ref>
===Television=== Sparks had his screen debut on the television movie ''[[Frog (film)|Frog]]'', starring [[Shelley Duvall]], [[Elliott Gould]], and [[Scott Grimes]] in 1987. Over the following decades he would go on to appear in several types of TV roles, which included host of ''[[Talk Soup]]'' in 1999, and was one of the stars of Disney XD's ''[[Lab Rats (US TV series)|Lab Rats]]''.
Sparks will portray Nelson in the second season of ''[[Fuller House (TV series)|Fuller House]]''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://tvline.com/2016/09/15/fuller-house-nelson-recast-hal-sparks-season-2-spoilers/|title=Fuller House Recast: Hal Sparks to Play D.J.'s Ex-Boyfriend Nelson in Season 2|last=Swift|first=Andy|last2=Swift|first2=Andy|date=September 15, 2016|website=TVLine|access-date=September 16, 2016}}</ref>
====Lab Rats/Bionic Island/Elite Force==== Hal portrayed Donald Davenport in [[Lab Rats (U.S. TV series)|Lab Rats]]. Donald is the older brother of Douglas Davenport (Jeremy Kent Jackson), the stepfather of Leo Dooley ([[Tyrel Jackson Williams]]), the husband of Tasha Davenport ([[Angel Parker]]) and the adopter of Adam, ([[Spencer Boldman]]), Bree ([[Kelli Berglund]]) and Chase ([[Billy Unger]]).
====Game shows==== Sparks became the United States' youngest game show emcee in 1988 when he hosted the short-lived, [[broadcast syndication|syndicated]] game show, ''[[Treasure Mall]]''.
He also participated on [[Game Show Network|GSN]]'s ''[[Extreme Dodgeball]]'' as captain of the Chicago Hitmen team.
He provided the voice of the computer named "Mr. Q" on the U.S television adaptation of ''[[20Q (game show)|20Q]]'', which aired on the Game Show Network (GSN) in 2009.
====VH1 appearances==== [[File:Hal Sparks, 2007.JPG|thumb|220px|Sparks in 2007]] Sparks was one of five celebrities to appear in the first episode of VH1's ''[[Celebrity Paranormal Project]]''. He has also been a regular commentator on several VH1 series, including the following: * ''[[I Love the '70s (U.S. TV series)|I Love the '70s]]'' * ''[[I Love the '80s (U.S. TV series)|I Love the '80s]]'' * ''[[I Love the '80s Strikes Back]]'' * ''[[I Love the '80s 3-D]]'' * ''[[I Love the '90s (U.S. TV series)|I Love the '90s]]'' * ''[[I Love the '90s: Part Deux]]'' * ''[[I Love the '70s: Volume II]]'' * ''[[I Love the New Millennium]]'' *''[[100 Greatest Hard Rock Songs]]'' *''[[Black to the Future]]'' * ''Undateable''
====TV starring roles==== Sparks was a regular cast member of the breakthrough [[Showtime (TV network)|Showtime]] television series, ''[[Queer as Folk (U.S. TV series)|Queer As Folk]]'', an American adaptation of the [[Queer as Folk (UK TV series)|UK series of the same name]] written by [[Russell T Davies]].
In 2007, Sparks became the voice of the lead character in the animated series for children, ''[[Tak & the Power of Juju]]'' for [[Nickelodeon]], which ran for twelve episodes between 2007 and 2008.
In 2009, Sparks recorded his first [[Showtime (TV network)|Showtime]] comedy special ''[[Charmageddon]]'' in front of a standing-room-only crowd at the OC Pavilion in Santa Ana, California. The special aired in 2010, and was released on DVD.
In 2011, Sparks was cast as Donald Davenport, one of the lead characters of a new Disney pilot ''[[Lab Rats (US TV series)|Lab Rats]]''. Variety reported on July 12, 2011 that the series was ordered by Disney for a 2012 premiere.<ref>{{cite news|title=Hal Sparks Tapped for Disney XD Pilot "Lab Rats"|url=http://www.levitymanagement.com/News/Hal-Sparks-Tapped-for-Disney-XD-Pilot--Lab-Rats-/19f4ebc0-febd-4823-ad17-1e1f5556c84d|date=April 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111006173921/http://www.levitymanagement.com/News/Hal-Sparks-Tapped-for-Disney-XD-Pilot--Lab-Rats-/19f4ebc0-febd-4823-ad17-1e1f5556c84d|archivedate=October 6, 2011|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Disney XD experiments with 'Lab Rats'|url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1118039791|publisher=Variety | first=Jon|last=Weisman|date=July 12, 2011}}</ref>
In early 2012, the ''[[Lab Rats (US TV series)|Lab Rats]]'' premiere received [http://www.deadline.com/2012/05/disney-xds-top-rated-series-lab-rats-renewed-for-second-season/ the highest ratings] for original series for the network. It was announced in May 2012, that it had officially picked up for another season.
====TV guest appearances==== Sparks had made appearances on various television programs from as early as 1994, when he played a long-haired skateboarder on the fourteenth episode of the first season of ''[[Lois & Clark: The New Adventures of Superman]]''. In 1995, he appeared in the "Gentle Horse" episode of ''[[Dr. Quinn, Medicine Woman]]''. From 2000 through 2006, he appeared in ''[[Martial Law]]'', ''[[Frasier]]'', ''[[One on One (TV series)|One on One]]'', ''[[CSI: Crime Scene Investigation]]'', and ''[[Las Vegas (TV series)|Las Vegas]]''.
He appeared as himself in the video "[[Beat It]]," the Michael Jackson cover, by [[Fall Out Boy]], and voiced a cameo on ''[[Robot Chicken]]''.
====Reality TV==== In 2006, Sparks competed for the charity [[Habitat for Humanity]] on the Fox celebrity competition ''[[Celebrity Duets]]''. He performed with such musical legends as [[Smokey Robinson]], [[Gladys Knight]], [[Wynonna Judd]], [[Dennis DeYoung]], [[Dee Snider]] and [[Sebastian Bach]]. He made it to the finale along with [[Lucy Lawless]] and [[Alfonso Ribeiro]], and came in third in the series.
In 2007, Sparks was cast as the host for the [[Warner Bros.|WB]] reality series ''[[Survival of the Richest]]'', where wealthy young adults were paired with those young adults with massive debts to complete challenges together and work as a team.
Also in 2007, Sparks joined [[Roseanne Barr|Roseanne]] to judge [[Nick at Night]]'s search for ''America's Funniest Mom''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Comedy Off Broadway: Hal Sparks|url=http://www.comedyoffbroadway.com/comics/hal-sparks|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110304174330/http://www.comedyoffbroadway.com/comics/hal-sparks|archivedate=March 4, 2011|df=}}</ref>
Sparks was a contestant on the 2008 VH1 celeb-reality series ''[[Celebracadabra]]'', where the celebrities vie to out-perform each other with magic they have learned from their experienced coaches. Other celebrity contestants competing included [[Ant (comedian)|Ant]], [[Lisa Ann Walter]], [[Carnie Wilson]], [[Christopher "Kid" Reid]], [[Kimberly Wyatt]], and [[C. Thomas Howell]]. Howell was the winner, with Sparks taking second place.
===Film=== His first breakout role in a mainstream movie was in the 2000 cult favorite ''[[Dude, Where's My Car?]]'', as [[Zoltan]], the bubble-wrapped leader of a clan of nerds obsessed with outer space. In a 2009 interview with We Are Movie Geeks, he confirmed he created the iconic hand gesture in a "Z" formation.<ref>{{cite web|title=WAMG Interview with Hal Sparks|url=http://wearemoviegeeks.com/2009/02/wamg-interview-hal-sparks/}}</ref> The "Z" hand gesture became the celebratory sign of choice among the members and fans of [[baseball|baseball's]] [[Pittsburgh Pirates]], of whom Sparks is a fan, starting in 2012.<ref>{{cite news|last=Starkey|first=Joe|title=No Dempster dive for Pirates|publisher=''[[Pittsburgh Tribune-Review]]''|url=http://triblive.com/sports/2265370-74/pirates-sparks-zoltan-dempster-starkey-believe-born-call-dive-dude|date=July 26, 2012}}</ref> On July 25, 2012, he threw out the first pitch during a Pirates/Cubs series at PNC Park.
Sparks has appeared in other films, including ''[[Dickie Roberts: Former Child Star]]'' and ''[[Spider-Man 2]]'', where he had a memorable cameo as the elevator passenger who enjoys an awkward but funny moment with Spider-Man. He also appeared in the opening scene of the 2009 [[Mike Judge]] film ''[[Extract]]'', as one of the guitar salesmen scammed out of a guitar by the con-woman played by [[Mila Kunis]].
In 2004, he starred as Deputy Dale in the independently produced ''[[Lightning Bug (film)|Lightning Bug]]'', which was written and directed by Robert Hall, who was an original bandmate in Hal's hard rock band Zero 1.
===Music=== In addition to acting, Sparks is also the lead singer and guitarist for a [[rock music|rock]] band, ZERO 1 (previously called The Hal Sparks Band). At the start, the band consisted of Hal himself, his friend Rob Hall on bass and Hal's cousin Miles Loretta on drums. Their self-titled debut album was released in December 2006 and produced by [[King's X]]'s frontman [[DUg Pinnick]]. The album is available through [[iTunes]] and on Sparks' official website.
In 2007, both Sparks and Loretta from Zero 1 participated on Doug's solo project ''[[Strum Sum Up]]''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Magna Cart Records: Dug Pinnick Strum Sum Up|url=http://www.magnacarta.net/releases/dugstrum.html}}</ref>
The band now has a new lineup consisting of Hal Sparks (lead vocals and guitar), Brian Crow (guitar and backup vocals), Bumper Renga (bass and backup vocals) and Lance Tamanaha (drums and backup vocals). They signed with the record label "rocket science" and have a new album on the way called "The sacred nothing". Also expected to debut is the band's first video for the single "American Psycho," which was directed by Adrienne Wanyo and filmed on location at the [[Houdini Mansion]].<ref>{{cite web|title=American Psycho Sneak Peek|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Bwf6TvI9pDk}}</ref>
Hal was a contestant in the first season of ''[[Celebrity Duets]]''. He often joins the Los Angeles cover band [[Steel Panther]] to sing classic 80s metal tunes, such as the [[Skid Row (American band)|Skid Row]] hit "[[Youth Gone Wild]]".<ref>{{cite web|title=HAL SPARKS sings Youth Gone Wild w/ METAL SKOOL|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sl1iz-jU9Os}}</ref>
===Stand-up=== In 2011, Sparks began touring the US with [[John Fugelsang]] and [[Stephanie Miller]] as part of the Sexy Liberal Comedy Tour.
In 2012, Sparks and Fugelsang began the "Politics, Sex and Religion Tour."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://crooksandliars.com/bluegal-aka-fran/conversation-hal-sparks|title=A Conversation With Hal Sparks|last=Langum|first=Frances|date=June 24, 2012|work=Crooks and Liars|access-date=May 6, 2018|language=en-US}}</ref>
==Personal life== Sparks is an outspoken activist who regularly participates in charitable events for organizations like [[AIDS Walk]], [[Farm Sanctuary]], the Lilli Claire Foundation, Imagine a Cure and the [[Marijuana Policy Project]]. However, he is [[straight edge]] and states to have never drunk, smoked or used recreational drugs.<ref>{{cite web|accessdate=March 19, 2018|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nHfdlLVYN1I|format=video|title=CNN: Comedian Hal Sparks: Legalize pot| publicationdate=June 9, 2011|time=1:32|website=[[YouTube]] ''(verified account)''|publisher=[[CNN]]}}<!-- Original CNN link with the video no longer available: http://edition.cnn.com/2011/LIVING/06/10/hal.sparks/index.html --></ref>
While at [[Los Angeles International Airport]] in 2010, Sparks and an airline passenger used [[Cardiopulmonary resuscitation|CPR]] on an unconscious, elderly man who had collapsed in the airport terminal.<ref>{{cite news|work=Dayton Daily News | title=Township woman helps comedian save man at LAX|url=http://www.daytondailynews.com/news/community/centerville/township-woman-helps-comedian-save-man-at-lax-870064.html|date=August 19, 2010}}</ref>
In May 2011, Sparks announced he would become a father during a special Ustream show on [[Father's Day]].<ref>{{cite web|title=HalSparksLive Ustream: Humpdays With Hal|url=http://www.ustream.tv./recorded/15544610|accessdate=June 22, 2011}}</ref> He debuted his son Camden Harrison Sparks at the 2011 AIDS Walk in Los Angeles.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://greginhollywood.com/queer-as-folk-alum-hal-sparks-is-a-dad-56764|title="Queer as Folk" alum Hal Sparks is a dad!|website=greginhollywood.com}}</ref>
Sparks has studied martial arts since the age of 8 years old and holds belts in Karate, Tae Kwon Do, and several forms of Kung Fu including Wushu.<ref>{{cite av media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=chwEl1ynua0|title=Lab Rats - Hal Sparks Interview|date=March 13, 2012|publisher=|via=YouTube}}</ref>
In 2012, the [[Pittsburgh Pirates]] began using the iconic "Zoltan" hand gesture from ''Dude, Where's My Car?'' as a good luck symbol to turn around a 19-season losing streak. After a [[Twitter]] campaign to encourage the "real Zoltan" to appear at a game, Sparks flew to [[Pittsburgh]] on July 25, 2012, to throw out the honorary first pitch, and was on hand to see the Pirates win 3-2 over his hometown team, the [[Chicago Cubs]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Majors|first=Dan|title=Actor who played Zoltan on hand for Pirates win |url=http://old.post-gazette.com/pg/12208/1249427-63.stm#ixzz21o9AtWED|newspaper=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette|date=July 26, 2012}}</ref> Despite picking up a cult following in Pittsburgh<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.post-gazette.com/stories/sports/pirates/the-pirates-believe-in-the-power-of-zoltan-643203/ | work=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette | first=Dan | last=Majors | title=The Pirates believe in the power of Zoltan - Pittsburgh Post-Gazette | date=July 4, 2012}}</ref> and helping the team contend in the playoff race well into September, the Pirates finished with a 79-83 record, extending their major North American professional sports record to 20 consecutive losing seasons.
Sparks is a [[Freemasonry|Freemason]], having been initiated on November 6, 2016, at Los Angeles Lodge No 42 F. & A. M.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://lodge42.org/welcome-bro-sparks|title=Los Angeles Lodge No. 42, Free and Accepted Masons of California » Welcome, Bro. Sparks|website=lodge42.org|language=en-US|access-date=April 5, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/HalSparksFangPage/photos/a.10150218335180055.451551.285684190054/10158248452620055/|title=Hal Sparks|website=www.facebook.com|language=en|access-date=April 5, 2017}}</ref>
As of April 2017, Sparks is a [[vegan]] and does intermittent fasting. He currently lives in [[Chinatown, Los Angeles]].<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.latimes.com/business/realestate/hot-property/la-fi-hp-my-favorite-room-hal-sparks-20170422-story.html| title=My Favorite Room: Hal Sparks converses with his 'punk feng shui' living space| author=Michelle Hofmann| date=April 21, 2017| publisher=Los Angeles Times| access-date=September 26, 2017}}</ref> He also does a political commentary talk show on the Chicago audio station [[WCPT (AM)|820 AM]] on Saturdays, which is uploaded on his YouTube channel.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.wcpt820.com/hal-sparks-3/| title=Hal Sparks Radio Program Mega-Worldwide| publisher=WCPT 820| access-date=September 26, 2017}}</ref>
